title: Kalamkari Art
hero_image_alt: Detailed Kalamkari painting depicting mythological scene
short_description: Hand-painted cotton textile art from Andhra Pradesh, produced using natural dyes and a 'kalam' (pen).
long_description:
Kalamkari literally means 'Pen Craft' (Kalam + Kari). While there are two styles, the Srikalahasti style is the one that is strictly 'drawn' using a bamboo pen (Kalam), and is thus considered a painting form. 

Originating in the temples of Srikalahasti, these paintings depict epic narratives from the Ramayana, Mahabharata, and Puranas. The artist uses a bamboo stick with a bundle of fine hair attached to one end as a brush/pen. The entire process uses natural vegetable dyes and involves multiple stages of washing and boiling the fabric.
traditional_methods: Fabric treatment with milk and myrobalan.

major_centres.title: Srikalahasti
major_centres.summary: The originators of the freehand drawing style.

authenticity_tips: Srikalahasti style is freehand, so lines will not be perfectly uniform unlike block prints. Smell of milk/dyes often persists.

seo_description: Explore Srikalahasti Kalamkari, the freehand painted textile art of Andhra Pradesh using natural dyes and epic themes.
